instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3115: What is 820-3115? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.LP8550: What is LP8550? This is an LED driver responsible for creating the backlight on the LCD screen of Macbooks from 2011 through 2015.
definitions.BKL_EN: What is BKL_EN? BKL_EN enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. .

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
had some liquid damage around thunderbolt and backlight driver
cleaned, still image but still no backlight
fuse was reading sketchy so replaced that
saw a small spark (since i was in the dark) on test power on but still no backlight
now <SIGNAL>PPBUS_S0_LCDBKLT_FUSED</SIGNAL>  reading 11.2V instead of 12v
both <RESISTOR>R9788</RESISTOR> & <RESISTOR>R9789</RESISTOR> voltage divider reading slightly above their values 
<RESISTOR>R9731</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R9715</RESISTOR> both reading 75k

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: ...did you replace <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>? Always replace it if liquid was nearby or contacts the chip.

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: <SIGNAL>BKL_EN</SIGNAL> present? Ball A5 of <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> ook good?

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message: 11.2v on AC power?  If yes check <RESISTOR>R0980</RESISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
pulled up the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP> and honestly that looks pretty good, when i get back i'll clean the solder and put a new one down
yes Duke 11.2V always on lcdbklt , been testing with a batt, i'll check ac when i get back
not sure what you meant by <RESISTOR>R0980</RESISTOR>

threads.title: [SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
[SOLVED]<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3115</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> no backlight
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R0910</RESISTOR> is good
turns out it was the <CHIP>LP8550</CHIP>, a little flickering first time turning on but seems all good now
